title.native: 雲のように風のように
title.romaji: Kumo no You ni Kaze no You ni
title.english: Like the Clouds, Like the Wind

description:
The country of Sokan is in turmoil. Following the death of the Emperor, a power struggle over the line of succession ensues. To cement the crown prince's rule, he must find a suitable bride. And so, the hunt for a new empress begins!

Ginga is a straightforward, lively country girl who joins the competition for the emperor's hand. Her earnest innocence shocks and reinvigorates the denizens of the palace. But can one girl's optimistic spirit help to save a kingdom facing threats both from within and without?

(Source: Discotek)

tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Age Gap
tags.description: Prominently features romantic relations between people with a significant age difference.

tags.name: Ojou-sama
tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田祐二) | [Studio Wyeth](https://www.studio-wyeth.jp/)

A prominent art director, as well as the founder and representative director of Studio Wyeth.

_Note: Not to be confused with animator [Yuuji Ikeda](https://anilist.co/staff/144426/)._

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/近藤勝也)

Famous for his character designs on numerous of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s films, which are considered the epitome of the Ghibli style.

After graduating from high school, he began working for [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/) at their Studio Annapuru. Under the direction of [Shinji Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/124192/), Kondou worked as a key animator of the TV anime series Cat's Eye. He then worked as a free agent on such shows as [The Mighty Orbots](https://anilist.co/anime/8130/), Rainbow Brite and Disney's Adventures of the Gummi Bears. His first work with Studio Ghibli was as a key animator on [Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/). After working on the Gainax film [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and multiple OVAs around late '80s, Kondou began to be known for the high quality of his work.

He has also collaborated collaborated with Kenichi Sakemi on a manga retelling of the Joan of Arc story, as well as doing the character designs for the Jade Cocoon video game series.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/近藤勝也)

Famous for his character designs on numerous of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s films, which are considered the epitome of the Ghibli style.

After graduating from high school, he began working for [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/) at their Studio Annapuru. Under the direction of [Shinji Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/124192/), Kondou worked as a key animator of the TV anime series Cat's Eye. He then worked as a free agent on such shows as [The Mighty Orbots](https://anilist.co/anime/8130/), Rainbow Brite and Disney's Adventures of the Gummi Bears. His first work with Studio Ghibli was as a key animator on [Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/). After working on the Gainax film [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and multiple OVAs around late '80s, Kondou began to be known for the high quality of his work.

He has also collaborated collaborated with Kenichi Sakemi on a manga retelling of the Joan of Arc story, as well as doing the character designs for the Jade Cocoon video game series.

(Source: Wikipedia)

He attended Fukuoka Prefectural Meizen High School, and then graduated with a major in Chinese philosophy at Aichi University in Nagoya. Sakemi uses many themes from Chinese history in his writing. He examines the meanings of freedom and imprisonment as well, even if this causes his stories to vary from historical fact. In addition to writing, Sakemi has also worked at a housing equipment company.  

Sakemi died on November 7, 2023, at the age of 59 due to respiratory failure. (Wikipedia)
He passed away due to a cardiac failure on January 23, 2009.

__Birth place:__ Arakawa, Tokyo, Japan

A writer for many anime, such as: Moomin, Kumo no yôni, kaze no yôni, Alfred J. Kwak and Ai no wakakusa monogatari. He also worked on many movies and TV shows.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/宮崎晃)
__Alma mater:__ Tokyo University of the Arts

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田祐二) | [Studio Wyeth](https://www.studio-wyeth.jp/)

A prominent art director, as well as the founder and representative director of Studio Wyeth.

_Note: Not to be confused with animator [Yuuji Ikeda](https://anilist.co/staff/144426/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1403759820679770114)

After graduating from Tokyo Designers' College, he joined [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/). In 1982, he made his debut as a key animator on the [Space Adventure Cobra](https://anilist.co/anime/2452/) film, and later also contributed in [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/) uncredited. He has since been wanted on many theatrical films, from [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/) to most of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s films. Due to this it has been a rarity to see him show up on TV productions.

He has been called the "Legendary Effects Giant" by [Mahiro Maeda](https://anilist.co/staff/100392/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大塚伸治)

The epitome of the versatile animator capable of adapting to any anime to do outstanding work in that style. Ootsuka's animation is professional but always full of personality and a special verve. 

He is one of the pillars of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s animation. Not confined to the Ghibli style, he has always searched for new means of expression, having done everything from the photorealistic to the cartoonish. The wonderful feeling of weight in the movement of Toshio running around the train station in [Only Yesterday](https://anilist.co/anime/1029/), the delightful bodyguards in [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597/), the little robot coming out of the water in the final episode of [FLCL](https://anilist.co/anime/227/) - all of these are quintessential Ootsuka. 

None other than the animation director of [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/) has conceded that the film was originally conceived as a project to showcase Ootsuka's talents, in the same way [Genma Taisen](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/) was a vehicle for [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/). Most of Ootsuka's scenes in the film were drawn entirely by himself, with no in-betweens, and his cuts which were the first finished, had a determining influence on the direction of the animation by the rest of the animators. 

(Source: [Pelleas](http://www.pelleas.net/animators/#20))

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/747930872179875840)

A pioneer in the field of realist animation, and then digital processing.

Debuted uncredited as an in-betweneer on [Zeta Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/85/). He made his initial splash in [Gundam 0080: War in the Pocket](https://anilist.co/anime/82/), and continued to develop his approach to animation which he calls "full limited," which eliminated the pose-to-pose feel of conventional keyframe animation. His characteristic animation can be seen in [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) and [End of Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/32/).

In [Blood: The Last Vampire](https://anilist.co/anime/405/), Iso experimented with digital processing of his hand-drawn fire effects, elevating it to uncanny realism. Iso then got his first taste of directing in [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/) episode 15, which he largely animated and also digitally processed himself.

His animation sensibilities, process innovations, experience in multiple levels of anime production, and interest in technology culminated in the 2007 sci-fi series, [Dennou Coil](https://anilist.co/anime/2164/), his veritable brainchild. During its production, there was a rumored falling-out with key staff. For the next several years, Iso would quietly animate under the pseudonym Mikio Odagawa.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

In 2018, he announced his retirement as an animator to focus exclusively on directing.

After graduating from Kanagawa Prefectural Yokosuka High School she began working for Telecom Film. In the later half of the 90s she worked often together with Daichi Akitarou, overseeing much of the work in his stead. She made her debut as director on Sister Princess RePure. One year later she directed Da Capo, where she was able to introduce even more of her own ideas and display her creative vision.
Noriko Moritomo is an animator and animation director.
